title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as the SEC. 30B Private Land Conservation. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act offers a tax credit to eligible farmers and ranchers for conservation contributions. The credit is 10% of the deduction allowed for qualified conservation contributions, with a maximum limit of $360,000 per year. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to $360,000 per year and can be allocated equally between spouses on a joint return. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to $360,000 per year and can be allocated equally between spouses on a joint return. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall not exceed the excess of certain limitations based on the amount of tax. Members of the same controlled group of corporations or persons under common control shall be treated as 1 taxpayer for aggregation purposes. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited based on the amount of tax. An eligible farmer or rancher is defined as a taxpayer with gross income from farming. The term 'eligible farmer or rancher' refers to an individual or C corporation with at least 60% of gross income from farming, and for a C corporation, the stock is not publicly traded on a recognized exchange. The section specifies that for a corporation to qualify as an eligible farmer or rancher, its stock must not be publicly traded on a recognized exchange, and the fair market value of its farming assets should not exceed $20,000,000. Additionally, special rules apply, including the requirement for the taxpayer to elect the application of this section for the taxable year, with the election being irrevocable. No deduction is allowed under section 170 for a qualified conservation contribution to a taxpayer who meets these criteria. The excess credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed by subsection (b)(2). The excess credit under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the next taxable year and added to the credit for that year. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. "Section 30B of the Act pertains to private land conservation, with amendments applying to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. Section 3 increases the charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers operating in corporate form." The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows qualified farmers and ranchers to be treated as individuals for charitable contribution purposes. This change applies to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. The amendment allows qualified farmers and ranchers to be treated as individuals for charitable contribution purposes, effective for taxable years ending after the enactment date. The amendment expands the estate tax exclusion for land under a qualified conservation easement, effective for estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
